reviewText:
CTU is obviously trying to be a successor to SWAT 4 and Rainbow Six 3. Which is great, we need a modern take on both games. Unfortunatly CTU falls short like all the other games that have tried.

First of all, CTU seems to be using the default Unity character controller. This leads to slippery" momentum based movement that feels just plain bad.
It ships with very few missions on top of the unskippable tutorial missions.
Poor pathfinding caused my ai teammates to get stuck on closed doors while they tried to reach me on the other side of the building many times.
Settings don't seem to save after closing and relaunching the game.

It's not all bad though. CTU has a few features that would have been welcomed in other games such as Takedown Red Sabre.
There's career progression in the form of recruiting new officers and purchasing different equipment
date: including a shield which was missing from SWAT 4.\nThere's a map editor. So if a large enough community forms
recommended: the lack of official missions could be fixed.\nYou can lean while walking
hoursPlayed: and leaning causes your character to "step out" making it really easy to check a corner.\nCTU allows you to play a "run and gun" style
voteText: or a slower "no casualties" style
helpfulPercent: and rewards you more for arrests over kills. This is nice to see in a police themed game.\n\nOverall
votesHelpful: there's a lot of potential here
votesTotal: but it's not worth it at it's current price and still needs a lot of work and polish. I would be a lot more hesitant to give this a thumbs down if it was an early access title. Keep looking SWAT players."

reviewText:
I think this game has the neatest idea.  BUT.  There is a ton of problems and i cannot recommend the game at all right now.

We were given 5 copies of the game to play this game together and show what it could be.   This game locked up, crashed, and never worked.  The single player works fine, but it isn't great.  The key to this game is the multiplayer, which we were so pumped for, and we were so dissapointed it failed over and over again.

I want this game to work, but do not buy it.  It should not have come out in it's current state.  The multiplayer needs to work.

reviewText:
CTU: Counter Terrorism Unit is both a bad game and a boring one.

There isn't a single aspect that this game does well.

Graphics:
I'm sure you've gleemed from the screenshots that these are dated and might have passed for servicable in 2001.
Really not worthy of any praise.

Sound:
The music in this game as far as I can tell is a generic action theme played on loop constantly, that's it, that one track.
The gun fire sounds are not satisfying at all, very rudimentary.
The voice acting is very mediocre.

Gameplay:
The controls are terrible.
The AI is terrible.
The gunplay is terrible.
The movement is terrible.
The 'player feedback' is terrible - i.e. nothing is there to tell you that you picked up evidence or you made progress toward a goal.

Content/value for money:
This game has 4 missions other than the tutorials. The first of which I completed, with no exaggeration, in the space of about 3 minutes. The second mission is a bunch of identical rooms in what I guess is a hotel, there are dark tight corridors and when you use the flashlight you can see the terrible shadows everywhere. Honestly there's barely anything to play here even if you were to overlook all of the problems.

Verdict:
This game is horrible and a waste of your time and money. I wanted to give it a chance, I love SWAT and Rainbow Six, I would have given this a positive review for sure if I derived any enjoyment whatsoever from it - I did not - in fact, I have to now ask for a refund. It was that bad.

reviewText:
CTU tries to create a similar experience to SWAT 4. Unfortunately it fails doing so for the most part. The game is not terrible and can potentially be fun with friends, but it's not the tactical shooter I was waiting for.

Mechanics:The game has a good variety of different mechanics (Snake cam, various grenade types, leaning). Unfortunately most of them are not very well implemented. This is especially true for the movement: It is floaty" meaning that you continue moving after releasing the key (even in "walk" mode). In general the controls feels unresponsive and clunky.

Level Design:The level design is actually decent. You have multiple ways to go and different angles to cover. Potentially creating interesing tactical decisions. The biggest downside is
date:
that there are only 4 different maps for the single player (+ 4 tutorial missions). There is a map editor in the game but it's in beta and is very bare bones. It has Steam Workshop integration however and a few people created maps already.

AI:The AI is in my opinion the most important part for a tactical shooter especially the one for your teammates. Unfortunately this is the weakest part of the game. You can order your squad mates to either go to a specific point or to follow you around. The first option is very finnicky if you try to make them face a specific direction. When following they sometimes get stuck (on terrain or on each other) but it works for the most part.
It gets bad when you try to open and clear a room. Their positioning in front of a door is terrible. When you tell to "Open and Clear" they will make one step into the doorframe and engage the first enemy in sight (which is usually the one diagonally across) blocking line of sight for you. Sometimes they bug out and attempt to clear the room they were coming from (doing a 180° turn in the door frame).
If you give the order to "Open
recommended:
Flash and Clear" they open the door (while not being in cover at all) and throw a flash greande in the room (which is ridiculously underpowered btw). If they don't see an enemy right away they will wait for the flash to go off and then attempt to clear the room. If they see an enemy though they will move into the room and try to engage him getting flashed by their own grenade.
The enemy AI is pretty bad as well and you get away with just run and gunning if you don't care for score (arresting people gives way more score than killing them).


ConclusionI think the game can be reasonable fun if you play it in co-op and restrict yourself to not play optimally and instead coordinate proper door breaches and stuff. The SP experience is very lackluster
hoursPlayed:
though. Definitely not the game I was hoping for.

More details:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0WkFO00b5Kg"
voteText: April 28

reviewText:
Product received for free

Full Bammsters article here:  http://bammsters.thang.dk/wordpress/ctu-counter-terrorism-unit-review/

Aside from the typical movement keys for a game of this type, the controls for the game are a bit wonky at times and don’t always make much sense. One blatant example of this that you can use the “Interact” key to pick up evidence, but when you take down an enemy that key does nothing. You have to use the spacebar to get the sub menu to come up and then click on the option to report back to your central command that they are down or have been arrested.
Then there are times when you shoot an enemy and they fly 10ft up into the air when they die before falling back to the ground. Not game breaking, more humorous than anything else but not something one would expect out of a finished product. One particularly annoying thing was that at times the AI would appear to surrender, only to go “Nope, nevermind” pull up their weapon and start shooting even though you had them dead to rights. It was bad enough that it made you just want to shoot any enemies rather than take the chance you’d get shot and not have enough health to take another hit before completing the map.


I was unable to test out multiplayer as I never did find anyone else playing, so unless you and a few friends are going to go in on a few copies together, expect to play this solo.


Even with the things mentioned before however, you could play the game and potentially have fun doing it. Visually it was OK but not an awesome looking game, and it is not all that fast paced, which one shouldn’t expect from a tactical shooter anyway, but the real game-breaking thing for me was that it never seemed to save my profile. Once I quit the game and would come back to it later none of my progress was saved and I would have to start from square one all over again. None of the upgraded weapons or gear I purchased, no extra guys on my squad, nothing.


The developers for the game are active on Steam from what I could see and are publishing regular updates, so it is possible that after more time in development and continued improvements that the game could become better and maybe at some point even worth the asking price.

reviewText:
Never realised I forgot to edit this, oh well.  A long time after I'll update my review.

Positives
+ The game is in active development, meaning things are still being fixed
+ In Game Editor works well
Negatives
- Movement feels really tanky, this is more noticable at lower fps' but its also slippery
- The Campaign is really short.
- AI Officers are useless. and all can die to a single guy
- It's hard to tell who you've called in, I'd prefer this part to be automatic after you kill someone or arrest someone as this can cause you to lose minutes if it glitches and doesnt complete or more likely you get distracted
- It didn't feel like I had to use any tatics.
- Low lighting situations look really bad for some reason.

How I played this game: Shoot anyone who points a gun at you.  Shoot anyone who doesn't put down their gun on sight.  Dont care about evidence.
Never hire extra officers.
Never change your equipment.  All you need is your two guns and you're set.

Suggestions
1. More missions, maybe a cohesive plot or something.  A narrative is always nice in a game.  Because at the moment this game reminds me of a flash game called Sierra 7 which I'd say actually had a BETTER story than this and while on rails and all stick figures worked really well.  And was free.
2.  At the moment there's no real community forming around the game, I'd point this at the fact the game itself isn't great and doesn't inspire much.  Hault work on the level editor for now, detail the levels more, as frankley the models aren't bad but it feels too clean, add decals, more models make it feel more alive.

Really this game feels like it's more early access than completed.  It really lacks that polish you look for in these games.
